ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also virtual group discussions in break-out rooms.
N/A
We used jamboard and other breakout groups to learn more. We also had workshops
We used out of class workshops and office hours to supplement our learning this semester.
We had a mandatory math section.
workshop classes which were virtual discussion sections.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Math and Calculus
Pre calculus knowledge and implications.
Beginning derivatives, logarithms, exponents.
math skills
VERY intro to calculus. Take this if you haven't even touched calculus. We did not get to the chain rule. Great course to enforce fundamental calculus.
I refreshed my math skills, and learned how to compute derivatives.
a lot of math skills
I learned how to use calculus to solve equations and I learned about mathematical terminology which bettered my understanding of mathematics and calculus as a whole.
I can understand derivatives.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The biggest weakness of this course, is that almost all of your learning is done outside of class. The subjects taught in class are rushed through, and ultimately require you to go to office hours to get taught by a ULA. The biggest strength comes from the fact that the ULA's are extremely kind, helpful and push you to actually master each concept taught.
Interactive with faculty and other students.
A strength is the class size, workload, and explanations. A weakness is not getting clear feedback from quizzes, exams, and homework.
struggled with math due to it being a long time since i took it
It was an awesome class.
Overall, very good course. Good assements and helpful problem sets. TA's were very helpful as they helped me multiple times through the semester.
I thought Dr Bobby taught this course very well, but I thoroughly enjoyed the breakout rooms and such. I think it could only be improved by being taught in person.
Teacher is great at  responding but was super hard to get engaged.. it was online though.

The strengths were definitely the workshops. I felt great about how well I understood the workshops. The problem that I had was that the quizzes were clearly much more difficult than anything else we did in class. I think if we practiced some upper level problems it would make much more sense to include them in the quizzes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms make zoom feel like a more normal classroom environment.
they were all great
I thought online breakout rooms and workshops were successful, but i did not think the online lectures were easy to pay attention to.
I think this course was done about as well as it could have been under the conditions,

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you have very little math experience, and feel the need to take a math course, I recommend this course, as there are lots of opportunities to get help and be successful in this course.
Yes
Yes, if they haven't taken calculus or precalculus before. It is a good introduction class and really helps you learn concepts in math.
yes dr bobby is a great teacher
Yes, the TA's were awesome and I really enjoyed this class.
I reccomend to those who have never taken a calculus course.
I would not because Math 112 is the same, but only requires one semester. For kids who like a slower pace, I would recommend Math 111.
yes, it is good to learn calculus

I might recommend this course to another student. I think in hindsight I would have gone with math 112 because of the whole covid scenario and my personal situation. I am not sure how math 112 is but this definitely felt fast paced still. My personal preparedness for this class my have been lower than my peers as well.
Yes, nice intro course into derivatives.
